ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think a large part of this course was just about music in general. What makes music? How do we capture the phenomenon that we call music in writing? What limitations arise from different notation systems? What are we trying to capture when we write down music? Then, we also explore other musics and the formal or informal theories surrounding them such as kiGogo music from Eastern Africa, Classical Japanese music, Indian music, and others. Discussions around ethnomusicology and the study of music outside of our own were central to the course. There was a bit of aural learning too.
I developed a musicological and music theoretic appreciation and perspective on several non-Western musics.
As a class, we learned about a number of musical practices from around the world, and then I had the opportunity to explore Arabic music in great depth individually.

1. A lot of stuff I'd call "critical comparative musicology" -- this was the more humanities-oriented part of the course. We would read papers by 19th-century musicologists, for example, and talk about what their methodology failed to capture, what assumptions they made, that sort of thing. A lot about the limits of music theory, etc. 2. The "music class" part of the course -- notation, singing, etc within the different traditions that we surveyed, learning to read music in Ian Quinn's funky invented universality-aspiring notation system. I thought the combination was very cool.
How to think about nonwestern musics and their theories

-A better understanding of transcriptions and theory outside of western staff notation and theory
-A depth of knowledge in a specific area of world musics from our midterm and final projects
knowledge of musical systems and traditions that fall outside of Western Art music; finding novel ways to respectfully engage with such musics through descriptive rather than prescriptive notation.

I learned something about how to analyze a few repertories of music beyond the Western world: first, we studied the repertoire of WaGogo music together for a few weeks, then I studied Carnatic music for my midterm and final. In class, after the first few weeks, we spent a few weeks in discussions led by a graduate student on historical readings in ethnomusicology and world music theory, then didn't have much of a curriculum.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish there was a little bit more structure to the discussions which sometimes went on tangents, but other than that the course was really great.

This course has a ton of potential - the material is exciting, and the music is fantastic. However, a little before halfway through the semester, the course took a turn for the worse. After that point, over half of the classes were cancelled, and I did not receive a grade on a single assignment. When class did happen, I found it engaging and intellectually exciting though.

The midterm and final projects were excellent! I feel like there wasn't enough warning about the midterm project, but I started reading my book near the beginning of the course so I was fine. It would've helped to have had more deadlines, like a deadline to choose a book for the project. Overall, it was a fascinating course!

I enjoyed the course content and the class overall, but there are a few things that I struggled with. 

The first was the class environment, which may have had more to do with the student body than the course itself. This was the first course at Yale that I felt nervous to speak in, as the course was dominated by a few loud men, who were not afraid to interrupt non-men while they were speaking and disparage their points. At times, classes would go by where not a single non-man spoke-- other times, only a few of us would speak up and get immediately interrupted or shot down. It was actually quite shocking to exist in that environment, especially since I haven't experienced anything like it in an academic setting at Yale.

Next, I wished there was more of a focus on people with lived experience with music and culture in the readings. Oftentimes, it seemed like we spent more time reading texts by white men with western music theory backgrounds than we did reading analyses of musics from the source. Since a lot of us mainly have experience with western music theory already, it felt like two degrees of separation between us and the music we were studying, because the authors were often white men. We had 11 authors featured in our readings throughout the course, and every single one of them was a man (or at least masculine presenting). Out of the 8 book options for the midterm, there was only 1 woman author, who was also white and frankly, racist. I understand that academics and music theory are male dominated, and this is an institutional problem, but I think that this course would be better overall with more non-male voices. There are a lot of women and nonbinary people who are changing the landscape of music theory and practice across the world, and I think it is disingenuous to portray music theory as both created and revolutionized almost exclusively by men.

With all of this being said, I want to reiterate that I learned a lot from this course, I appreciate all of the time, effort, and kindness of Professor Quinn, and I really did take a lot away from the experience. This was a very unique semester, but I hope that some of this feedback can be carried into the future of the course, because I think it is a valuable piece of the music department's offerings.

I enjoyed the singing exercises that we did and would have like to continue them through the latter part of the semester. Extenuating circumstances made it difficult to meet for every scheduled course meeting, but we made the most of it.

The course started very strong  Prof. Quinn had great ideas about how to discuss the material and what types of things we should think about. However, the course dropped off a lot after the very beginning it would have been nice if it had continued/if we had had more material in the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We had to make videos and recordings of ourselves singing. These were really fun and engaging for the course.
The Zoom seminars were engaging and inclusive, but more breakout rooms might have been nice as well.
Singing!
minor technical difficulties with screen/audio sharing that were ultimately overcome
Classes were fine when they happened/were organized.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Professor Quinn is super nice, and the readings will kind of blow your mind changing the way you think about music.

I would recommend this course in a different semester for sure. I think this course has the potential to be fantastic if all of the classes are actually held, and a clear week by week syllabus is defined.
I would absolutely recommend this course, especially if you have a specific interest in a non-Western musical practice that you want to explore independently!

This really depends. If you're looking for an interesting class that will not be too much work and will be thought-provoking and cool, for sure take it. If you're not going into music or majoring in it or anything, this is probably one of the only opportunities you'll have to think like this. None of the work will feel like a burden -- there's not much of it, and all of it is thought-provoking and interesting. That being said, if you're the sort of person who will be frustrated by disorganization, this might not be the class for you. Ian is the sweetest man in the world, but he is a bit of a mess. A lot of that was due to the fact that this has just been a rough semester (COVID) for everyone and him specifically, but I think part of it is probably just who he is (there was never a real syllabus for the course, for example).
Yes. I learned a lot about a variety of world musics, and I enjoyed the opportunity to 'specialize' in a certain type of music through my midterm and final projects.
Absolutely! Definitely a very interesting course that challenges our tendency to box all kinds of music into Western notation and conventions. A great way to broaden your musical horizons.
If the beginning of the course had continued over the whole semester, it would have been good. However, I don't think the abridged semester was worth it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Sometimes recorded lecture.
Asynchronous assignments in lieu of class.
Singing exercises, notation
N/A
n/a
We had virtual classes, ostensibly twice a week, but they were often cancelled. At the beginning they often had clearer format, but towards the end they became office hours-style.
